poem:
Title: "Frames in Rebellion"

In the vein of Tito's cameraman, 
the world takes form.
Projections, stirring, like Yugoslavian mornings,
in each reel, dreams of anti-colonialist fervor bloom. 

Through a lens, a history
etched onto film's fragile skin.
Thin as truth, ever-warped by light and shadow,
the narrative unspools. 

Caught in the crossfire,
cinematic guerrillas dance -
a ballet of idealism and illusion,
a testament to the sovereignty of perception.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Ciné-Guerrillas/Non-Aligned: Scenes from the Labudović Reels review – thoughtful and worthwhile It’s well worth watching this pair of pensive documentaries by Mila Turajlić, which, through the person of Marshal Tito’s preferred cameraman Stevan Labudović, highlight and question the role of film-making in forging political narratives. The first, Ciné-Guerrillas: Scenes from the Labudović Reels (★★★★☆), is directly focused on the lenser’s own history; in particular a key episode when, as part of Yugoslavia’s global anti-colonialist push,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
